topics.title: What Is a Logical Fallacy?

hook.text: An argument can sound persuasive, feel logical, and still be completely wrong. That's a fallacy.

buildup.text: A logical fallacy is a flaw in reasoning that undermines an argument's logic â€” regardless of whether the conclusion is true.

discovery.text: Aristotle cataloged 13 fallacies in 350 BC. Two millennia later, we've identified over 100 â€” and still fall for them.

twist.text: A fallacy doesn't mean the conclusion is wrong. It means the reasoning doesn't support it.

climax.text: Fallacies persist because they mimic good reasoning. They're convincing â€” that's what makes them dangerous.

punchline.text: Bad logic can reach good conclusions. That's the trap.

quiz.question: What does a logical fallacy mean about a conclusion?
options: The reasoning doesn't support it, but it could still be true
The argument was made in bad faith

topics.title: Formal vs. Informal Fallacies

hook.text: Some fallacies break the rules of logic itself. Others play by the rules but cheat with content. Both are deadly.

buildup.text: Formal fallacies: the logical structure is invalid. 'If A then B; B; therefore A' â€“ wrong regardless of what A & B are.

discovery.text: Informal fallacies: the structure may be valid, but the content is flawed â€“ irrelevant evidence, hidden assumptions.

twist.text: Most real-world fallacies are informal. Nobody argues in pure syllogisms â€“ they argue in stories, analogies, & emotions.

climax.text: Formal fallacies are detectable by machines. Informal fallacies require human judgment â€” which is itself biased.

punchline.text: Logic errors are easy to catch. Persuasion errors are not.

quiz.question: What is the key difference between formal and informal fallacies?
options: Formal have flawed structure; informal have flawed content
Informal are only used in debates

topics.title: Why Fallacies Are So Persuasive

hook.text: Fallacies survive because they work. A politician who uses them wins more votes than one who uses pure logic.

buildup.text: Our brains are wired for quick pattern-matching, not careful logic. Fallacies exploit those shortcuts.

discovery.text: Many fallacies piggyback on emotions â€” fear, pride, anger, belonging. Emotion reaches the brain faster than reason.

twist.text: Even knowing about fallacies doesn't make you immune.

climax.text: The best defense isn't spotting fallacies in real-time â€“ it's slowing down & asking: 'Does this evidence actually.

punchline.text: Fallacies feel like logic. That's the whole point.

quiz.question: Why do people fall for fallacies even when trained in logic?
options: Fallacies exploit fast emotional processing that bypasses careful reasoning

topics.title: The Fallacy Fallacy: Calling Out Errors Incorrectly

hook.text: 'You used an ad hominem! Therefore your conclusion is wrong!' That itself is a fallacy. Welcome to the meta-level.

buildup.text: The fallacy fallacy: assuming a conclusion is false because the argument for it contains a fallacy.

discovery.text: Bad arguments can reach true conclusions. 'The sky is blue because unicorns said so' â€” bad reasoning, true conclusion.

twist.text: Internet debates are plagued by this. People cry 'fallacy!' as if naming it disproves the claim. It doesn't.

climax.text: The proper response to a fallacy is 'Your reasoning is flawed' â€” not 'Your conclusion is wrong.'

punchline.text: Finding a bad argument isn't the same as proving it wrong.

quiz.question: What is the fallacy fallacy?
options: Assuming a conclusion is false because the argument for it is fallacious
Using too many fallacies at once

topics.title: A Brief History of Fallacy Hunting

hook.text: Aristotle was the first fallacy hunter. His 'Sophistical Refutations' in 350 BC was the original myth-busting guide.

buildup.text: He identified tricks used by Sophists â€” paid teachers of persuasion who cared about winning, not truth.

discovery.text: Medieval scholars expanded the list. John Stuart Mill, Bentham, and Schopenhauer added new categories in the 1800s.

twist.text: Today we have over 100 named fallacies. Yet political ads, social media, and daily arguments use the same ancient ones.

climax.text: The tools to detect flawed reasoning have existed for 2,400 years. We just don't teach them in school.

punchline.text: Aristotle gave us the playbook. We forgot to read it.

quiz.question: Who first systematically cataloged logical fallacies?

topics.title: Ad Hominem: Attacking the Person, Not the Argument

hook.text: 'You're not a scientist, so your climate data doesn't count.' The data is either valid or it'sn't, regardless of who.

buildup.text: Ad hominem: attacking the person making the argument instead of addressing the argument itself.

discovery.text: It comes in flavors: abusive (you're stupid), circumstantial (you're biased), and tu quoque (you do it too).

twist.text: Sometimes character IS relevant â€“ a pathological liar's testimony matters less.

climax.text: Ad hominem is the most common fallacy in political debate.

punchline.text: Attack the argument, not the arguer. Or admit you can't.

quiz.question: When is ad hominem a fallacy?
options: When character attacks replace engagement with the actual argument

topics.title: Straw Man: Fighting an Argument Nobody Made

hook.text: 'We should reduce military spending.' 'So you want to leave us completely defenseless?' Nobody said that.

buildup.text: Straw man: misrepresenting someone's argument to make it easier to attack, then defeating the distorted version.

discovery.text: It works by exaggeration, oversimplification, or taking a position to its most extreme possible interpretation.

twist.text: Straw men are often unintentional. We genuinely misunderstand opposing views because we don't listen carefully.

climax.text: The antidote: 'steelmanning' â€” restating the opponent's argument in its strongest possible form before responding.

punchline.text: If you can't state their argument fairly, you haven't understood it.

quiz.question: What is 'steelmanning'?
options: Restating the opponent's argument in its strongest form before responding

topics.title: Appeal to Emotion: Heart Over Head

hook.text: A charity ad shows a starving child. It raises millions. A report with the same data raises nothing. Emotion won.

buildup.text: Appeal to emotion: substituting emotional reactions (fear, pity, anger, pride) for logical evidence.

discovery.text: Sub-types include appeal to fear (ad baculum), appeal to pity (ad misericordiam), and appeal to flattery.

twist.text: Emotion isn't always irrelevant. Ethics requires empathy.

climax.text: Demagogues master this: make people angry first, present your solution second. The emotion does the persuading.

punchline.text: Feeling it doesn't make it true. But it makes it convincing.

quiz.question: When does appeal to emotion become a fallacy?
options: When emotional reactions replace logical evidence as justification

topics.title: Red Herring: Changing the Subject

hook.text: 'Why did you miss the deadline?' 'Well, the whole project was poorly planned from the start.' The subject just changed.

buildup.text: Red herring: introducing an irrelevant topic to divert attention from the original issue.

discovery.text: The name comes from smoked herring, which was dragged across trails to mislead hunting dogs.

twist.text: Red herrings are powerful because the diversion is often interesting.

climax.text: Politicians are masters: 'What about your tax plan?' 'Let me tell you about my opponent's record on...' Redirect.

punchline.text: An interesting answer to the wrong question is still no answer.

quiz.question: What makes a red herring effective?
options: The diversion is interesting enough that people forget the original question

topics.title: Tu Quoque: Two Wrongs Make a Right?

hook.text: 'You should stop smoking.' 'But you smoke too!' The health effects of smoking don't change based on who says it.

buildup.text: Tu quoque (you too): deflecting criticism by pointing out the critic does the same thing. Also called 'whataboutism.'

discovery.text: Soviet propaganda perfected it: any criticism of the USSR was met with 'And you're lynching Negroes' â€“ a real Soviet.

twist.text: It's psychologically satisfying because it feels fair. But consistency of the speaker doesn't affect truth of the claim.

climax.text: Tu quoque is the internet's favorite fallacy.

punchline.text: Hypocrisy doesn't make someone wrong. It makes them a hypocrite.

quiz.question: Why is tu quoque a fallacy?
options: The speaker's hypocrisy doesn't affect the truth of their claim

topics.title: Begging the Question: Circular Reasoning

hook.text: 'The Bible is true because it's the word of God. How do we know? The Bible says so.' The conclusion is the premise.

buildup.text: Begging the question: the conclusion is hidden in the premises. It's circular reasoning â€” using your claim to prove itself.

discovery.text: Aristotle identified it as 'petitio principii.' It often hides in complex language so the circularity isn't obvious.

twist.text: Many common arguments beg the question: 'Free markets are best because economic freedom is the highest value.' That's.

climax.text: The fallacy often goes unnoticed because the premise and conclusion are phrased differently, disguising the repetition.

punchline.text: If your proof is your conclusion rephrased, you've proven nothing.

quiz.question: What is begging the question?
options: An argument where the conclusion is assumed in the premises

topics.title: False Dilemma: Only Two Choices?

hook.text: 'You're either with us or against us.' Really? There's no middle ground, no third option, no nuance at all?

buildup.text: False dilemma: presenting only two options when more exist.

discovery.text: Also called 'black-or-white thinking.' Real issues almost always have more than two possible positions.

twist.text: Politicians love this: 'Either we cut taxes or the economy collapses.' Both could be wrong. A third path could exist.

climax.text: The fix: whenever someone presents two options, ask 'What are options three, four, and five?'

punchline.text: Life isn't multiple choice with only two answers.

quiz.question: What is a false dilemma?
options: A difficult choice between two real options
Presenting only two options when more exist

topics.title: Slippery Slope: The Domino That Never Falls

hook.text: 'Allow calculators in class and soon they'll forget math and civilization collapses!' Quite the leap in logic.

buildup.text: Slippery slope: arguing that one event will inevitably lead to a chain of increasingly extreme consequences.

discovery.text: The fallacy isn't claiming consequences exist â€“ it's assuming each step inevitably follows without proving the causal.

twist.text: Sometimes slopes ARE slippery â€“ addiction, authoritarianism, ecological collapse.

climax.text: Test each link: 'Does A really cause B? Does B really cause C?' If any link breaks, the slope doesn't slide.

punchline.text: Dominoes only fall if they're actually touching.

quiz.question: When is a slippery slope argument valid?
options: When each causal link in the chain is supported by evidence
When the final outcome is extreme enough

topics.title: Hasty Generalization: One Example Isn't a Pattern

hook.text: 'I met a rude person from that country. People from there must be rude.' One data point. 7 billion people. Sure.

buildup.text: Hasty generalization: drawing a broad conclusion from a sample that's too small or unrepresentative.

discovery.text: It's the foundation of stereotyping.

twist.text: Media amplifies this: one plane crash creates 'flying is dangerous.' One tech CEO success creates 'drop out of college.'

climax.text: Good reasoning asks: How large is the sample? Is it representative? Are there counterexamples?

punchline.text: Anecdotes are not data. No matter how vivid.

quiz.question: What makes a hasty generalization fallacious?
options: Drawing conclusions too quickly in time
Drawing broad conclusions from a sample that's too small or unrepresentative

topics.title: No True Scotsman: Moving the Goalposts

hook.text: 'No Scotsman puts sugar in his porridge.' 'Angus does.' 'Well, no TRUE Scotsman puts sugar in his porridge.'

buildup.text: No True Scotsman: redefining a group to exclude counterexamples rather than accepting that the claim was wrong.

discovery.text: Antony Flew coined it in 1975.

twist.text: You see it everywhere: 'Real Christians don't do that.' 'A true patriot would never...' The definition shifts to win.

climax.text: The fallacy makes claims unfalsifiable.

punchline.text: If you keep changing the definition, you aren't making an argument.

quiz.question: What is the 'No True Scotsman' fallacy?
options: Redefining a group to exclude counterexamples rather than accepting the claim was wrong

topics.title: Equivocation: When Words Shift Meaning

hook.text: 'A feather is light. What is light cannot be dark. Therefore, a feather cannot be dark.' Sounds logical. It's not.

buildup.text: Equivocation: using a word with two different meanings in the same argument, treating them as if they're the same.

discovery.text: 'Light' meaning 'not heavy' is different from 'light' meaning 'bright.' The argument swaps definitions mid-stream.

twist.text: Real examples: 'The law says all men are equal' shifts between legal equality & biological sameness in political.

climax.text: Equivocation is how word games win debates. Pin down definitions at the start, and the trick collapses.

punchline.text: Same word, different meaning. That's not logic â€” it's a trick.

quiz.question: What is equivocation?
options: Using a word with two different meanings as if they're the same

topics.title: The Loaded Question: Trapped Before You Answer

hook.text: 'Have you stopped cheating on exams?' Whether you answer yes or no, you've admitted to cheating.

buildup.text: A loaded question contains a hidden assumption. Answering it accepts the assumption, even if it's false.

discovery.text: Lawyers, journalists, and debaters use loaded questions to corner opponents into admissions they didn't intend.

twist.text: The correct response isn't yes or no â€” it's rejecting the premise: 'I reject the assumption in your question.'

climax.text: Most survey questions are subtly loaded. 'Do you support the wasteful government spending plan?' presumes it's wasteful.

punchline.text: Before answering a question, check what answering it admits.

quiz.question: What makes a question 'loaded'?
options: It contains a hidden assumption that any answer would accept

topics.title: Amphiboly: Grammatical Ambiguity as a Weapon

hook.text: 'The professor said on Monday he would give the exam.' Did he say it on Monday, or is the exam on Monday?

buildup.text: Amphiboly: a fallacy where grammatical ambiguity allows a sentence to be interpreted in multiple contradictory ways.

discovery.text: The Oracle at Delphi used it masterfully: 'A great empire will be destroyed' â€“ the king assumed it meant the enemy's.

twist.text: Legal contracts are carefully drafted to avoid amphiboly. A misplaced comma once cost a Canadian company $2 million.

climax.text: In arguments, amphiboly lets people claim they meant the other interpretation â€” a built-in escape hatch.

punchline.text: If a sentence can mean two things, assume the speaker will pick whichever helps.

quiz.question: What is amphiboly?
options: Grammatical ambiguity allowing multiple contradictory interpretations

topics.title: The Motte-and-Bailey: Retreating to Safe Ground

hook.text: Make a bold, controversial claim. When challenged, retreat to an obvious, defensible claim. Claim victory.

buildup.text: Named after medieval castles: the bailey is the valuable land, the motte is the fortified hill you retreat to when.

discovery.text: Nicholas Shackel identified this in 2005. It uses two claims â€” one strong but indefensible, one weak but undeniable.

twist.text: 'All art is political'. Challenged? 'Art can have political themes'. The retreat looks like the original claim.

climax.text: Motte-and-bailey is devastating because the arguer never admits to switching.

punchline.text: If they keep switching between claims, pin them to one.

quiz.question: What is the motte-and-bailey fallacy?
options: Defending a castle in an argument
Retreating from a bold claim to a defensible one when challenged, then acting as if they're the same

topics.title: Appeal to Nature: Natural Doesn't Mean Good

hook.text: 'It's natural, so it must be good for you.' Arsenic is natural. So are earthquakes, cancer, and poison ivy.

buildup.text: Appeal to nature: arguing that something is good because it's natural, or bad because it's artificial.

discovery.text: David Hume identified the is-ought problem: you can't derive what SHOULD be from what IS in nature.

twist.text: The $200 billion 'natural products' industry is built on this fallacy.

climax.text: Nature is indifferent to human welfare. Whether something is good requires evidence of outcomes, not origin.

punchline.text: Natural or not, show me the evidence.

quiz.question: Why is the appeal to nature a fallacy?
options: Being natural doesn't determine whether something is good or bad

topics.title: Correlation vs. Causation: Together Doesn't Mean Because

hook.text: Ice cream sales and drowning deaths both rise in summer. Does ice cream cause drowning? No. Heat causes both.

buildup.text: Correlation: two things happen together. Causation: one thing causes the other. They look identical but aren't.

discovery.text: A hidden third variable (confound) often explains both. Or the causation runs backwards. Or it's pure coincidence.

twist.text: A famous spurious correlation: US spending on science correlates 99.79% with suicides by hanging. Obviously meaningless.

climax.text: To prove causation, you need controlled experiments, temporal precedence, and elimination of alternative explanations.

punchline.text: Together doesn't mean because. Always ask: what else could explain this?

quiz.question: Why doesn't correlation prove causation?
options: A third variable, reverse causation, or coincidence could explain the relationship

topics.title: The Gambler's Fallacy: Luck Doesn't Have Memory

hook.text: A roulette wheel lands on red 10 times in a row. You bet on black because 'it's due.' The wheel doesn't remember.

buildup.text: The gambler's fallacy: believing that past random events affect future random events. They don't.

discovery.text: In 1913 at Monte Carlo, black hit 26 times straight. Gamblers lost millions betting on red, convinced it was overdue.

twist.text: The inverse exists too: the 'hot hand fallacy.' If a basketball player makes 5 shots, we expect a 6th.

climax.text: Each flip, spin, or roll is independent. Probability doesn't 'balance out' â€” that's a human invention.

punchline.text: The coin doesn't know what happened last time.

quiz.question: What is the gambler's fallacy?
options: Believing past random events affect future random events
Gambling more than you can afford

topics.title: Post Hoc Ergo Propter Hoc: After Therefore Because?

hook.text: 'I wore my lucky socks and we won the game.' Your socks didn't cause the victory. Sequence isn't causation.

buildup.text: Post hoc ergo propter hoc: 'after this, therefore because of this.' Assuming that because B followed A, A caused B.

discovery.text: It's the basis of most superstitions. A rooster crows before dawn â€” but the rooster doesn't cause the sunrise.

twist.text: Medical quackery exploits this ruthlessly. Take a remedy, then improve naturally. You credit the remedy.

climax.text: To prove causation over temporal sequence, you need repeated trials, control groups, and mechanism.

punchline.text: What came first isn't necessarily what caused it.

quiz.question: What does 'post hoc ergo propter hoc' mean?
options: After this, therefore because of this â€” falsely assuming sequence equals causation

topics.title: Simpson's Paradox: Data That Lies When Combined

hook.text: UC Berkeley was sued for gender bias in admissions. The overall data showed bias. But every department favored women.

buildup.text: Simpson's Paradox: a trend that appears in several groups reverses when the groups are combined.

discovery.text: Women applied to competitive departments with low admission rates. Men applied to easier ones. Aggregating hid this.

twist.text: A drug can be better for men AND better for women individually, but worse for the combined population.

climax.text: Simpson's Paradox shows that aggregated data can tell the exact opposite story from disaggregated data. Both are 'true.'

punchline.text: The data doesn't lie. But the summary might.

quiz.question: What is Simpson's Paradox?
options: A trend that appears in groups but reverses when groups are combined
A statistical error caused by small samples

topics.title: Fallacies in Advertising: How Brands Trick Your Brain

hook.text: '9 out of 10 dentists recommend...' Recommend what? Over what? Who funded the study?

buildup.text: Ads use bandwagon, appeal to authority, and false dilemma.

discovery.text: Weasel words do the heavy lifting: 'helps fight,' 'up to 50% off,' 'part of a balanced diet.' Technically true.

twist.text: Advertisers don't need you to believe the claim â€” just to remember the brand. The fallacy creates the memory.

climax.text: Advertising spending exceeds $700 billion/year globally. It wouldn't exist if fallacious persuasion didn't work.

punchline.text: If the logic doesn't hold up, the jingle still will.

quiz.question: What are 'weasel words' in advertising?
options: Technically true phrases that imply more than they prove
Words that sound like animal names

topics.title: Fallacies in Politics: The Playbook of Power

hook.text: In a single debate, a candidate used ad hominem, straw man, false dilemma, and appeal to fear â€” within three minutes.

buildup.text: Political rhetoric relies on fallacies because elections reward persuasion, not accuracy.

discovery.text: The most common political fallacies: whataboutism, slippery slope, bandwagon, appeal to tradition, & false equivalence.

twist.text: Fact-checkers exist, but corrections reach far fewer people than the original claim. The fallacy wins the speed race.

climax.text: Democracies depend on citizens detecting bad arguments. Fallacy literacy is a civic skill, not an academic one.

punchline.text: The ballot doesn't check your logic. That's your job.

quiz.question: Why do political debates feature so many fallacies?

topics.title: Conspiracy Theories: A Fallacy Ecosystem

hook.text: Every conspiracy theory is an interlocking web of fallacies â€” each one shielding the others from falsification.

buildup.text: They use circular reasoning (the cover-up proves the conspiracy), ad hominem (critics are shills), and unfalsifiability.

discovery.text: Evidence against the theory becomes evidence for it: 'They're hiding the truth!' This makes the theory immune to.

twist.text: Real conspiracies do exist â€“ Watergate, Enron.

climax.text: The litmus test: 'What evidence would change your mind?' If nothing could, you're not reasoning â€” you're believing.

punchline.text: If no evidence can disprove it, it's not a theory. It's a faith.

quiz.question: What makes conspiracy theories resistant to debunking?
options: Evidence against them is reinterpreted as evidence for them

topics.title: How to Argue Without Fallacies

hook.text: Knowing 100 fallacies is useless if you can't construct a sound argument yourself. Offense matters, not just defense.

buildup.text: Step 1: State your claim clearly. Step 2: Provide relevant evidence. Step 3: Show how the evidence supports the claim.

discovery.text: The strongest move: acknowledge counterarguments before the opponent raises them, then explain why your position.

twist.text: Admitting uncertainty is a strength, not a weakness.

climax.text: The goal isn't to win â€” it's to find truth together. Arguments are collaborative truth-seeking, not verbal combat.

punchline.text: The best argument is one you'd accept if someone else made it.

quiz.question: What is the strongest rhetorical move in an argument?
options: Acknowledging counterarguments before the opponent raises them
Using as many facts as possible

topics.title: Fallacy Detection: A Practical Toolkit

hook.text: You don't need to memorize 100 Latin names. Three questions catch 90% of fallacies in real conversations.

buildup.text: Question 1: 'Does this evidence actually support this specific conclusion?' This catches irrelevance fallacies.

discovery.text: Question 2: 'What's being assumed but not stated?' This catches hidden premises, loaded questions, & circular reasoning.

twist.text: Question 3: 'What would change my mind?' If nothing could, your position is unfalsifiable â€“ & you might be the fallacy.

climax.text: Apply these three questions to your own arguments first. Self-testing is more valuable than catching others' errors.

punchline.text: Three questions. Most fallacies detected. No Latin required.

quiz.question: Which question helps catch hidden assumptions in arguments?

topics.title: The Regression Fallacy

hook.text: A coach screams at players after a terrible game. Next game, they improve. Proof that yelling works?

buildup.text: Extreme performances tend to be followed by more average ones. This is regression to the mean â€” a statistical fact.

discovery.text: The regression fallacy: mistaking this natural statistical tendency for the effect of an intervention.

twist.text: Sports Illustrated cover jinx, sophomore slumps, miracle cures after worst days â€” all regression to the mean.

climax.text: Without a control group, you can't distinguish intervention effects from natural regression.

punchline.text: After your worst day, tomorrow is probably better anyway.

quiz.question: What is the regression fallacy?
options: Believing that society is getting worse
Mistaking regression to the mean for an intervention's effect
